answer_html: Do not worry about the presence of a negative sign, a negative loop current just means that the current (\(i_1\) and \(i_3\) in this case) actually flows counter-clockwise, not clockwise like we assumed.

current just means that the current ($i_1$ and $i_3$ in this case)
actually flows counter-clockwise, not clockwise like we assumed.
hints_html: Current source, E is on a branch shared by two loop currents, how do you resolve that?
hints_latex:
Current source, E is on a branch shared by two loop currents, how do you
resolve that?
hints_raw: Current source, E is on a branch shared by two loop currents, how do you resolve that?
question: A 11
sols_html:
To figure out the current on the current source E, we must choose which direction we will cross the source. It shouldn’t matter which direction we take and so we will show both possibilities.

Traverse the current source from bottom to top:

Here we are moving with current 2 (\(+i_2\)) and against current 1 (\(-i_1\)). E has a current of 9A in the upward direction (indicated by the arrow). Since we are moving upwards then the current is +9A. Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}i_2-i_1=9A.\end{aligned}\]

Traverse the current source from bottom to top:

Here we are moving with current 1 (\(+i_1\)) and against current 2 (\(-i_2\)). E has a current of 9A in the upward direction (indicated by the arrow). Since we are moving downward then the current is -9A. Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}i_1-i_2=-9A.\end{aligned}\]

Notice that these are the same equation as they should be.

Full Solution for Those Interested:

If people are looking to practice there work with circuits, we can continue work from here and from A10 to solve for the unknown voltages and loop currents. Based on the same reasoning in A10 we can get that the Kirchhoff linear equation for loop 1 is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}-6+i_1+v_1=0\end{aligned}\]

where recall that positive numbers mean voltage drops (across the resistors and across the current source since it points upwards while our clockwise current points downwards there) and that negative numbers mean voltage gains (across the battery since we move from the negative to positive terminal). We already have the second loop from A10 as

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}2i_2+4(i_2-i_3)+7+3i_2-v_1=0\end{aligned}\]

and so the third and final loop is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}4(i_3-i_2)+5i_3+8=0\end{aligned}\]

where the \(4\Omega\) resistor has a voltage drop since we’re moving in the direction of current loop 3 but a voltage gain from current loop 2.

So far we only have 3 equations for 4 unknowns; the last one comes from the current source. From above we already have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}i_2-i_1=9.\end{aligned}\]

We can write this in a matrix problem as

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & 1\\ 0 & 9 & -4 & -1\\ 0 & -4 & 9 & 0\\ -1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} i_1\\ i_2\\ i_3\\ v_1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 6\\ -7\\ -8\\ 9 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

We can write this is an augmented matrix as

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cccc|c} 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 6\\ 0 & 9 & -4 & -1 & -7\\ 0 & -4 & 9 & 0 & -8\\ -1 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 9 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

which we can row reduce to get

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cccc|c} 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & -8.4595\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0.5405\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & -0.6486\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 14.4595\\ \end{array}\right].\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we see that our solution is

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} i_1\\ i_2\\ i_3\\ v_1\\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -8.4595\\ 0.5405\\ -0.6486\\ 14.4595 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Do not worry about the presence of a negative sign, a negative loop current just means that the current (\(i_1\) and \(i_3\) in this case) actually flows counter-clockwise, not clockwise like we assumed.
sols_raw:
To figure out the current on the current source E, we must choose which direction we will cross the source.  It shouldn't matter which direction we take and so we will show both possibilities.

'''Traverse the current source from bottom to top''':

Here we are moving with current 2 (<math>+i_2</math>) and against current 1 (<math>-i_1</math>).  E has a current of 9A in the upward direction (indicated by the arrow).  Since we are moving upwards then the current is +9A.  Therefore,

:<math>
\displaystyle{}i_2-i_1=9A.
</math>

'''Traverse the current source from bottom to top''':

Here we are moving with current 1 (<math>+i_1</math>) and against current 2 (<math>-i_2</math>).  E has a current of 9A in the upward direction (indicated by the arrow).  Since we are moving downward then the current is -9A.  Therefore,

:<math>
\displaystyle{}i_1-i_2=-9A.
</math>

Notice that these are the same equation as they should be.


<br />
'''Full Solution for Those Interested:'''

If people are looking to practice there work with circuits, we can continue work from here and from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2010/Question_A_10|A10]] to solve for the unknown voltages and loop currents.  Based on the same reasoning in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2010/Question_A_10|A10]] we can get that the Kirchhoff linear equation for loop 1 is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}-6+i_1+v_1=0
</math>

where recall that positive numbers mean voltage drops (across the resistors and across the current source since it points upwards while our clockwise current points downwards there) and that negative numbers mean voltage gains (across the battery since we move from the negative to positive terminal).  We already have the second loop from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2010/Question_A_10|A10]] as

:<math>
\displaystyle{}2i_2+4(i_2-i_3)+7+3i_2-v_1=0
</math>

and so the third and final loop is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}4(i_3-i_2)+5i_3+8=0
</math>

where the <math>4\Omega</math> resistor has a voltage drop since we're moving in the direction of current loop 3 but a voltage gain from current loop 2.  

So far we only have 3 equations for 4 unknowns; the last one comes from the current source.  From above we already have that

:<math>
\displaystyle{}i_2-i_1=9.
</math>

We can write this in a matrix problem as

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  0  &  0  &  1\\
0  &  9  &  -4  &  -1\\
0  &  -4  &  9  &  0\\
-1  &  1  &  0  &  0
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
i_1\\
i_2\\
i_3\\
v_1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
6\\
-7\\
-8\\
9
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

We can write this is an augmented matrix as

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cccc|c}
1  &  0  &  0  &  1 & 6\\
0  &  9  &  -4  &  -1 & -7\\
0  &  -4  &  9  &  0 & -8\\
-1  &  1  &  0  &  0 & 9
\end{array}\right]
</math>

which we can row reduce to get

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cccc|c}
1  &  0  &  0  &  0  &  -8.4595\\
0  &  1  &  0  &  0  &  0.5405\\
0  &  0  &  1  &  0  &  -0.6486\\
0  &  0  &  0  &  1  &  14.4595\\
\end{array}\right].
</math>

Therefore we see that our solution is

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
i_1\\
i_2\\
i_3\\
v_1\\
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
 -8.4595\\
  0.5405\\
  -0.6486\\
  14.4595
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Do not worry about the presence of a negative sign, a negative loop current just means that the current (<math>i_1</math> and <math>i_3</math> in this case) actually flows counter-clockwise, not clockwise like we assumed.
